6.40.text:
Welcome back to my Dark Corner of This
World.

8.88.text: "It was regretable you ever left us."

10.88.text:
When alien invaders land on Earth what's
the first thing they do?

14.27.text: Blow stuff up? Kidnap women? Or...

17.53.text: "We'd like a loan from your bank."

21.81.text: This only happens in British films.

24.73.text: Only in England would alien invaders apply for a small business loan to fund their invasion.

37.64.text: This is 'They Came From Beyond Space'.

39.92.text:
which follows a scientist apparently
played by BBC Breakfast's Bill Turnball

44.34.text: "I also happen to be in love with you"

46.04.text: Who in between scoring with much younger women...

48.98.text: "I might even make you a cup of tea."

50.88.text:
Tries to solve the mystery of what aliens
are doing on a small farm.

55.34.text: And it really is a mystery.

57.81.text:
"When the right time comes you'll
understand."

61.01.text:
You say that, but for the vast majority of
this film

64.42.text: I had and no idea what was going on.

67.94.text: "I don't know, can't make it out."

77.43.text: "Control of vocal cords akward... but adequate."

92.68.text: aliens that can be trapped just by closing the rain hood of your car.

107.16.text: "Conquer and rule Earth, why would we want to do that?"

110.51.text:
And each time I hero achieves something,
breaking into the farm,

122.36.text:
Overcoming every alien he meets with
frankly baffeling ease.

133.46.text: I expect a little more the plot to be revealed.

136.12.text: "I've come to tell you why you're here."

140.22.text: but surely the rescued girlfriend will be able to tell us what's going on.

149.64.text: Now this withholding of information can work, in films like the 39 Steps for example

154.38.text: because it puts us into the same position as the hero desperate to know what's going on...

159.76.text: and not knowing what to do.

161.24.text: "We've got to keep them from taking off."

163.24.text:
Why? I have all the information
you have...

166.66.text: and I don't know why that's essential.

168.42.text: "I would like to know what's going on down here."

170.38.text:
Doctor Curtis keeps telling us he has
no idea what's going on,

173.40.text:
but he acts as if he knows exactly what's
going on.

176.44.text: "I don't belive in any of this."

178.48.text: He figures out the alien tech,

183.85.text: builds a helmet to prevent mind control,

188.90.text:
and no point does he demonstrate
even the slightest surprise that aliens have invaded Cornwall

197.15.text:
Now personally I think that about half
way through even the most patient viewer

201.74.text:
is going to decide that life is just too
damn short and give up.

205.14.text:
But if you do hang on to the end that is
a full explanation.

209.38.text: The aliens are stranded on the moon

211.48.text: "The ship crashed on this moon of your Earth."

215.40.text: Despite being able to pilot meteorites in formation to get to Earth.

219.80.text: "Good heveans, it looks like shooting stars, a whole flock of them."

222.26.text:
and they need to get into Doctor Curtis'
mind to be able to build their rocket home.

227.09.text: "There is knowledge there that we need, it's been too long withheld."

231.44.text: "what possible satisfaction of glory could we find...

234.82.text: "in ruling a race who's most intelligent life force...

244.97.text:
But, those massive plot holes aside does
all add up

249.30.text: and it turns out it's all just a terrible misunderstanding

253.15.text:
and everything is sorted out with a firm
handshake.

260.82.text:
Which is a very British way  of ending a
film,

263.02.text: it's just not a very satisfying wayof dealing with this slave meant if humanity
